aws::graph::propositions: # Robinson Helicopter Accident in Red Oak, Iowa
The accident occurred in Red Oak, Iowa.
The accident occurred on July 14, 2012, at 17:50 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Robinson Helicopter Company R44 II.
The defining event was collision during takeoff/land.
The flight was conducted under Part 137: Agricultural regulations.
The accident number was CEN12LA443.
The aircraft registration was N556MM.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There was 1 person involved in the accident with no injuries.
The pilot was unable to activate the motorized spray system after arriving at the field to be sprayed.
The pilot returned to the departure location to troubleshoot the inoperative spray system.
The pilot maneuvered the helicopter to land next to a ground-support vehicle.
The helicopter's main rotor system impacted a landing platform installed on top of the ground-support vehicle.
The pilot reported no preimpact mechanical malfunctions or failures that would have precluded normal operation of the helicopter.
The wind near the time of the accident was reported as calm.
In the absence of mechanical malfunctions or adverse atmospheric conditions, the pilot should have been able to maintain proper distance from the known obstacle.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of this accident to be the pilot's failure to maintain clearance from the ground-support vehicle during landing.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "Ground vehicle - Response/compensation" as an environmental issue finding.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "Monitoring environment - Pilot" as a personnel issue finding.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Red Oak, Iowa

## Date & Time: 
July 14, 2012, 17:50 Local

## Aircraft:
Robinson Helicopter Company R44 II

## Defining Event:
Collision during takeoff/land

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 137: Agricultural

## Accident Number:
CEN12LA443

## Registration:
N556MM

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis
The pilot reported that he was unable to activate the motorized spray system after arriving at the field to be sprayed. He returned to the departure location in order to troubleshoot the inoperative spray system. As he maneuvered the helicopter to land next to a ground-support vehicle, the main rotor system impacted a landing platform installed on top of the vehicle. The pilot reported that there were no preimpact mechanical malfunctions or failures that would have precluded normal operation of the helicopter. The wind near the time of the accident was reported as calm. In the absence of any mechanical malfunctions or adverse atmospheric conditions, the pilot should have been able to maintain proper distance from the known obstacle.

## Probable Cause and Findings
The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be: The pilot's failure to maintain clearance from the ground-support vehicle during landing.

## Findings
Environmental issues | Ground vehicle - Response/compensation
--- | ---
Personnel issues | Monitoring environment - Pilot

---
